title: Protocol for generating human immune system mice and hydrodynamic injection to analyze human hematopoiesis in vivo
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Mouse irradiation
Timing: Approximately 20 min
This step describes the key operations for total body irradiation of NCG pups.
Turn on and pre-heat the irradiator.
4–6 days old pups (no more than 15 pups) from a ventilated cage along with some bedding were transferred into one autoclaved plastic box, then close the box lid (Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A and 1B).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1468-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. The irradiation process of pups
(A) Transfer pups from a ventilated cage into an autoclaved box.
(B) A plastic box with the lid closed.
(C) Irradiate the pups using a RS-2000 Rad Source Irradiator.
Critical: The operation should be conducted under a biological safety cabinet. And the following irradiation process should be finished within 30 min. Otherwise, pups would be suffocated.
Wrap the individual box with autoclaved paper bags and take it out of the facility.
Note: If the irradiator is inside the animal facility, jump steps 3 and 7, and follow the procedure dictates of the facility.
Put the plastic boxes one at a time into the irradiator (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C).
Set the sub-lethal irradiation dose (63 s, 70 cGy X-ray for NCG mice) and start the irradiation process.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1468_6.csv

Critical: The immunodeficient mouse strains for HIS mice generation could be typically classified into SCID mice or Rag mice regarding to their mutation of Prkdc or Rag1/Rag2 respectively. SCID mice are sensitive to irradiation due to their mutation in Prkdc(Biedermann et al., 1991[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]), whereas Rag mice are relatively resistant to irradiation. Thus, precautions need to be taken when choosing a starting irradiation dose for optimization. The reported sublethal doses of mouse pups from different strains are listed (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]). As indicated, for SCID mice, the sublethal irradiation dose test should be set between 60 and 110 cGy, e.g., 60, 70, 80, 90, 100, 110 cGy. While for Rag mice the initial dose for sublethal irradiation escalation test should start from 2 Gy, e.g., 2, 2.5, 3, 3.5, 4 Gy.
Take out the plastic box when the radiation process finishes and move on to irradiate the next one.
Remove paper bags when entering the animal facility.
Transfer the plastic boxes carrying irradiated pups into a biological safety cabinet and open the lids.
Note: Avoid introducing foreign scents or contaminations during the process. Otherwise, the parental mice may kill or stop feeding the pups.
Recovery of CD34+ HSCs from cryopreservation
Timing: 30 min
Take out one vial of previously cryopreserved CD34+ HSCs from liquid nitrogen (put the tube in liquid nitrogen or dry ice if transfer process is required) and immediately put it into a 37°C water bath.
Quickly thaw the cells by gently swirling the vial in the water bath.
Take out the vial and spray it with 70% ethanol and then transfer it into a biological safety cabinet.
Open the vial and transfer the cells into a centrifuge tube containing 10 mL pre-warmed cell medium.

Count the live cells using 0.4% trypan blue solution (dilute the sample at 1:1 ration) with a KOVA™ Glasstic™ Slide under microscopy.
Centrifuge the cells at 500 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Carefully aspirate the upper supernatant and resuspend cells to the concentration of 105 cells/50 μL with RPMI 1640 injection medium.
Intrahepatic HSC injections
Timing: Approximately 1–2 h, about 2 min per mouse
Load a 29 gauge 1 mL BD insulin syringe with resuspended HSCs.
Take one pup and hold it head down with fingers applying gentle pressure to restrict the movement of pups and expose the abdomen. Then the red-colored liver can be seen just adjacent to the white-colored stomach (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1468-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Posture for intrahepatic injection
Hold the syringe with the other hand and insert the needle at a 45-degree angle into the pup’s liver about 3 mm depth.
Note: Always follow the role of handling sharps and needles during the process.
Inject 50 μL medium slowly into the liver and hold still for 3 s.
Release the pressure of your fingers from the injected pups, then pull out the needle slowly and put the pups back to the plastic box.
Repeat the above steps until all the injections are finished.
Wean HIS mice at 21 days old and wait for 10 weeks after the HSCs injection before further humanization level analysis.
Note: It takes effort and practice to be proficient at intrahepatic injection, starting from practicing with culture medium/PBS instead of HSCs.
Flow cytometry analysis of humanization level
Flow cytometry analysis of the blood of HIS mice is a convenient and standard approach to obtain the humanization information. This section describes the detailed steps on humanization level determination, including the blood collection and the further immune phenotype analysis using flow cytometry.

Facial vein bleeding of HIS mice
Timing: About 1 min per mouse
This step describes the blood draw from HIS mice. Drawing blood from mouse facial veins is routinely employed in our facility. Alternative methods such as retro-orbital blood collection and blood collection from the tail are also applicable. We choose facial vein bleeding method over retro-orbital and tail vein bleeding as this approach causes less stress to the mice and cost less time than other approaches.
Take one HIS mouse out of the cage and properly restrain it with one hand.
Note: Properly restraining the mice and applying adequate pressure to the maxillary vein is a prerequisite for a smooth blood draw.
Visualize the mark of the maxillary vein: albino NCG mouse has an obvious mark for the maxillary vein, which is viewed as a small bald spot (shown in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A). The maxillary vein is just under this spot.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1468-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Drawing blood from the submandibular vein
(A) Red arrow indicates the bald area where the submandibular vein locates.
(B) Insert the needle directly into the bald area.
(C) Peripheral blood comes out of the submandibular vein.
Puncture it with a 23 gauge needle, withdraw the needle quickly and then collect 50 μL blood using an anticoagulant tube (Figures 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B and 3C).
Apply gentle pressure with an alcohol pad on the site of the puncture to stop the bleeding.
Dispose the needle into a sharps/biohazard container.
Repeat the above steps until the blood draw of all the mice is finished.
Note: Always use a new sterile needle to bleed each HIS mouse. Do not share needles for different mice to avoid cross-contamination.
FACS analysis of the blood samples
Timing: Approximately 1–2 h, it takes about 2 h for 20 mice

Prepare fluorescent antibody cocktail containing the antibodies in Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2].
table:files/protocols_protocol_1468_7.csv
Note: For a basic detection of human immune cell reconstruction level, antibodies against human CD45, human B cells (CD19/CD20), T cells (CD3) as well as mouse CD45 are necessary. The choice of antibody fluorochrome conjugates in this protocol is optimized for flow cytometer available in our facility. As such, antibody panels should be adjusted according to the parameter of the available flow cytometer.
Add 6 μL/well antibody cocktail into a 96 well round bottom plate.
Transfer 50 μL of blood from each blood sample to the 96 well round bottom plate and incubate for 30 min at 4°C, protecting from light.
Dilute 10× BD FACS™ Lysing Solution to 1× with ddH20, then add 200 μL lysing buffer to each sample after the antibody staining process and incubate for 10 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Spin the plate at 500 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Note: Repeat the lysing process if there are red blood cells remaining. Alternatively, the red blood cells can be lysed with ACK (RBC lysis buffer) first and then proceed for antibody staining process.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 200 μL of ice cold FACS buffer or cell buffer.
Transfer the cell suspension into a flow tube by passing through a 70 μm cell strainer.
Store the samples on ice and wait for further flow cytometry acquisition.
Acquire the samples to collect the desired volume of sample using available flow cytometer.
Note: For detailed guidelines and description of flow cytometer set-up when performing flow cytometry experiments please refer to (Cossarizza et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]; Prosser et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib17]; Rico et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib18])

Analyze FCS files using flow cytometry analysis software. We routinely use NovoExpress Software or FlowJo for flow cytometer data analysis (a gating strategy is shown in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1468-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Gating strategy for FACS analysis of blood samples from HIS mice
Determine the cell number of human CD45 (hCD45) per mL blood as：
   c e l l  n u m b e r  p e r  m l =   c e l l  c o u n t  o f  h C D 45  f r o m  a c q u i r e d  s a m p l e    a c q u i r e d  v o u l m e  p e r  s a m p l e   × t o t a l  v o l u m e  p e r  s a m p l e × 20 .  
Note: Here, 20 is the quotient of 1000 μl/50 μl blood.
And calculate the humanization levels of the HIS mice using the following formula:
 %  o f  h u m a n i z a t i o n  l e v e l =   %  o f  h C D 45   %  o f  h C D 45 + %  o f  m C D 45   × 100  % . 
The HIS mouse with a hCD45 cell number above 105/mL or a humanization level above 10% is used for further experiments. And HIS mice assigned to different groups should have matched gender and similar humanization levels.
Hydrodynamic injection
Timing: Steps 40–41 take about 20 min and steps 42–49 cost about 1 min per mouse

Hydrodynamic injection is a procedure to express proteins of interest in mouse liver by rapid injection of large volume of plasmids DNA solution into the tail vein of mouse. The following steps describe the detailed procedures for hydrodynamic injection, including plasmids solution preparation and tips for the injection.
Prepare the plasmid solution using a 50 mL tube as shown in Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3].
table:files/protocols_protocol_1468_8.csv
Note: The values for A and B are determined follows: A- The amounts of plasmids injected positively correlate with protein expression levels. But the range of protein expression varies considerably and need to be individually determined. B- Typically, a maxi-prep would yield a stock plasmid concentration of 500 μg/ml to 1500 μg /ml.
Critical: Plasmids should be endotoxin-free. Otherwise, it would lead to mouse death after injection.
Weigh the mice and prepare the injection solution as shown in Table 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl4].
table:files/protocols_protocol_1468_9.csv
Load the injection solution to a 2.5 mL syringe with a 26 gauge needle.
Critical: Tap the syringe to remove all the air bubbles in the syringe.
Pre-heat the mice with a heat lamp for 15 min to increase the visibility of the lateral caudal veins.
Put one HIS mouse in a restraining device and firmly immobilize the mouse (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1468-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Hydrodynamic injection
(A) Ensure the mouse still can breathe freely after being restrained in the immobilizer.
(B) Insert the needle into the later tail vein and finish the injection within 7 s.
Note: Make sure the mouse still breathes freely.
Pull and straighten the tail of the mouse with your non-dominant hand.
Hold the syringe by the other hand with the bevel of the needle facing upward and nearly parallel to the lateral caudal vein, then insert the needle smoothly into the vein (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B).

Inject the solution quickly within 7 s, otherwise, the transfection efficiency would be extremely low.
Note: Always start the injection from the tip of the tail to ensure that more attempts could be carried out. If the solution cannot be injected completely at a single injection, inject the remaining solution again into the other later tail vein immediately. If two injections cannot be finished within 1 min, the transfection will not be successful. And the mouse should not proceed for further experiments.
Immediately release the mouse from the restrainer and put it back into the cage.
Critical: Remove the mouse from the restrainer immediately after the injection, or it may cause mouse death due to suffocation. The mouse may remain motionless for 10–30 min after hydrodynamic injection due to temporary arrhythmia. Usually, the mouse will recover within 10 min. On the condition that the breathing of the mouse turns out to be really shallow, gently massage the abdomen of the mouse to facilitate breathing.
Collect 100 μL of blood from the submandibular vein 24 h after the hydrodynamic injection as described from steps 23–28.
Centrifuge the blood at 2,000 × g for 10 min at 4°C.
Transfer the blood plasma into a new sterilized 0.5 mL tube.
Store the blood plasma at −80°C for ELISA analysis.
Note: ELISA analysis of the plasmid coding protein is done according to the manuals of the corresponding ELISA MAX™ Deluxe Set from Biolegend.
FACS analysis of human hematopoiesis and immune cells
Timing: Approximately 2–3 h, it takes about 3 h for 10 mice
This part demonstrates the basic analysis of human hematopoiesis and immune cells after hydrodynamic injection. Here we take the HIS mice that receive phIL-10 hydrodynamic injection as an example.

7 days post hydrodynamic injection, mice are sacrificed and the spleens are harvested in a 6 well plate containing 5 mL FACS buffer or cell buffer.
Gently mince the spleen through a 100 μm cell strainer with a 5 mL syringe piston.
Transfer the splenocytes into 15 mL centrifuge tubes and spin at 500 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Aspirate the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 1 mL Red Blood Cell Lysing Buffer Hybri-Max, incubating the cells at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 10 min.
Add 9 mL FACS buffer to stop the lysis and filter the cells into a new 15 mL tube by passing through a 70 μm cell strainer.
Spin down the cells at 500 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Aspirate the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 5 mL FACS buffer.
Count live cells using 0.4% trypan blue solution (dilute the sample at 1:1 ration) with a KOVA™ Glasstic™ Slide under microscopy.
Adjust cell concentration and transfer one million live cells per mouse in one well of a 96 well round bottom plate and spin down the cells at 500 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Prepare the blocking buffer in 50 μL FACS buffer per sample during centrifugation.
Discard the supernatant by flicking the plate over a sink.
Resuspend the cells by adding 50 μL blocking buffer and incubate at 4°C for 15 min.
Prepare the flow antibody mix as the panel in Table 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl5].
table:files/protocols_protocol_1468_10.csv
table:files/protocols_protocol_1468_11.csv
Note: The cell subpopulations are defined by cell surface markers according to Table 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl6].
Add 200 μL ice cold FACS buffer and spin down the cells at 500 × g for 5 min at 4°C.

Discard the supernatant, resuspend the cells with previously prepared 50 μL antibody mix and incubate at 4°C for 30 min, protecting from light.
Add 200 μL ice cold FACS buffer and spin down the cells at 500 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Discard the supernatant, resuspend the cells with 200 μL ice cold FACS buffer.
Transfer the cells into a flow tube by passing through a 70 μm cell strainer.
Acquire the samples to collect the desired volume of sample with a flow cytometer.
Analyze FCS files using NovoExpress Software or FlowJo (representative results are shown in Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).
